definition: An interjection (विस्मयादिबोधक) in Sanskrit is a word or phrase used to express strong feelings or sudden emotions, such as surprise, joy, pain, or excitement.

categories.description: Interjections in Sanskrit can be categorized into different kinds based on their function and context. These interjections are used to express emotions, reactions, or call attention.

onekinds.pain: पीड़ा या दु:ख के विस्मयादिबोधक (Interjections of Pain)

categories.description: Interjections in Sanskrit function to convey emotions and reactions in a spontaneous manner. They often stand alone or are followed by a sentence that elaborates on the feeling.

emotion_expressions: वाह! कति सुंदरं दृश्यं (Wow! What a beautiful sight).
आह! मम पाँवः पीडितः अस्ति (Ah! My foot is hurting).
attention_catchers: हे राम! त्वं कुत्र गच्छसि? (O Rama! Where are you going?)
क्या! येषां वयं मृषा तं कार्यं अपूर्णं (What! They left the task incomplete?).

categories.description: These interjections are used to express different emotions in various contexts. The interjections can either stand alone or be incorporated into sentences.

threekinds.function: These express a sudden strong emotion such as surprise or excitement.
threekinds.example: वाह! कति सुंदरं दृश्यं (Wow! What a beautiful sight).

threekinds.function: These interjections express discomfort, pain, or distress.
threekinds.example: आह! मम पाँवः पीडितः अस्ति (Ah! My foot is hurting).

threekinds.function: These are used to attract attention or address someone directly.
threekinds.example: हे राम! त्वं कुत्र गच्छसि? (O Rama! Where are you going?).
